HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY El 1927

VOL. XXXI, No. 51

MARYLAND TRACKMEN
DEFEAT BLUE JAYS
Three

Records Fall in Hard
Fought Dual Meet

GWYNN HOPKINS STAR
• Only Black and Blue Man to
Score Two Victories
Maryland defeated Hopkins, 75
2-3 to 50 1-3, in the annual dual
meet held at College Park last Saturday.
The Old Liners evinced such a
superiority in the track event that
the outcome of the contest was never
in doubt. The Black and Blue were
able to collect only 23 points in these
races while Maryland more than
doubled this number with a total of
49.

MILITARY CIRCLE
INITIATES SIX
One army officer and five
undergraduates were initiated
by Company I, Second Regiment, of Scabbard and Blade
into membership in that organization, Saturday. The ununit
initiates
dergraduate
were Thomas N. Biddison,
Charles Harris, Henry Piet,
Charles Waters, and H. Ridgely Warfield. The initiation of
these men was held at the
Hopkins Club Saturday after
the Navy lacrosse game. Major Hamilton, of William and
Mary College, was also taken
into the organization at that
time.

Records Broken

Neuman of Maryland was the first
record breaker of the day, when he
lowered the 880 yard record, a full
second, setting a new mark of 2
minutes 2 2-5 seconds.
In the next race, the two-mile
grind, Captain Gwinn ran easily to
set a new mark of 10 min. 3-5 sec.
This race was "all Hopkins" from
the gun. For the first mile Schiebel
remained out in front. In the final
half of the race these two Jays alternated in the van and came down
the stretch, striding side by side.
With the Maryland runners far in
the rear.
The last record to fall was that in
the broad jump. Viviell of Hopkins
/
2 in.,
set up a new mark of 22 ft. 21
exceeding by 4 inches the old record
of Aaronson of Hopkins. The 120
Yd. high hurdle record of 16 2-5 sec.
Was tied by . Sheriff Of— Maryland
who was pressed by Vivell throughout the race.

Blue Jays Secure
Important Contract

DR. ROBINSON CHAIRMAN
OF ATHENS COLLEGE
FUND COMMITTEE
Hopkins Professor in Charge of Quota
for Baltimore; Two Students
Receive Scholarships

Dr. C. K. Swartz, Collegiate Professor of Geology, is giving a series
of lectures on "Fundamental Problems Concerning Relations of Science and Religion" on successive
Thursdays for four weeks. The
first was given last Thursday. Room
5 in the C. E. Building was packed
to the door and the S. R. 0. sign
Was in order. Many graduate students in Philosophy were present
and expressed a lively interest in the
discussion.
Dr. Swartz said he felt it was incumbent upon him to give outlet to
his views on this subject. To his
mind, students will get most out of
their university course if they issue
from the school with a correct and
not a distorted philosophy of life.
This was by way of introduction.

Opposition Tomorrow

Catholic University will be met
on the Hopkins tennis courts today.
The varsity team was to have played
C. U. on April 27, but the match
had to be postponed on account of
the rain. Georgetown will visit
Homewood tomorrow and although
it is expected that Emmett Pare will
not play because of the freshman
ruling, Captain Hebner anticipates a
titanic struggle.
Darkness found Catholic University and the Jays tied in a memorable racquet festival over at Washington last year. Captain Hebner's
team feels that the issue in this
match Kill be decided before twilight settles on the clay courts.

TITLE REMAINS SECUgE
Sterling Work of Goal-keepers
Features Fast Game
With their coveted crown hanging in the balance, the Johns Hopkins stickmen fought and won the
greatest battle of their career, while
7,000 lacrosse fans nervously followed every play which made lacrosse history last Saturday at
Homewood.
Under the blazing afternoon sun,
the triumphant Black and Blue team
that has emerged victorious from so
many gruelling tests, put every
ounce of skill and energy forward
to come through once more the victors, this time humbling the undefeated Navy twelve by the close
margin of 6-5.
Goalkeepers Are Stone Walls

For a full five minutes while
both Middy and Jay twelves poured
a relentless fire of shots upon each
others' goal tenders, it seemed that
neither side would score with such
impregnable bulwarks to watch the
nets as Gazze and Finn. The small
Hopkins goalie seemed to cover
the whole mouth of the net, as well
aimed shots rolled off his arfns, his
legs, his chest, and even his head,
while the husky Middy net guardian's swift moving stick seemed to
have stretched until it formed a net
in front of Navy's goal.
The whole outcome of the great
struggle hinged on which of the
two hard-hitting offense machines
could first break the opposing defense. Finally, the smooth running
Hopkins machine broke through
when Biddison "goosed" the ball
from the bottom of the piled up
Navy defense past the falling Middy goal keeper after ten minutes of
hard maneuvers.
Farinholt Scores

make the men work hard to retain

Once having broken through the
tight Navy defense line, the Hopkins attack gradually gained impetus, as fed by Lang and Biddison, their well-aimed shots began to
take effect. Farinholt was the second of the Jay attackers to tally
when he sent a long shot through
the entire Middy defense.
Meanwhile the Middy attackers
were not idle. Led by Hull, their
small but agile inhome, they continued their incessant fire upon the
wary Finn, until Gardner Mallonee
and his goal defenders were able to
form a hole-proof line around the
Jay's net. Then for some minutes
neither team scored until Hull managed to slip through the line and
score the visitors' first goal.

A COMPLAINT
Though the Maryland Free State is recognized as the center
of lacrosse interest in the United States, it is unfortunate indeed
that the good old game is not accorded more recognition in other
states than we think it deserves. For example, the eminent New
York Times, a paper which advertises that it covers completely
all important events in the sport world, not only failed to report'
the Hopkins-Navy game, but did not contain one lacrosse writeup in its Sunday edition.
Perhaps the sports editor of the Times might not consider
college
game attended by seven thousand spectators an impora
tant sporting event, but we doubt even that. We can only wonder
why the news of the game was omitted.

NOTE ON LAST WEEK'S TRIAL
It is almost inevitable that the honor system should break
down on occasion. Until Hopkins becomes transformed into
Utopia, we can do nothing more than hope for a close approach
to perfection. And as we have said in these columns before, we.
believe that the system at this University works as well as human
beings will let it.
Therefore, when such an unfortunate occurrence as was experienced last week is brought to light, some of the chronic worriers on the campus begin to fear for the souls of their comrades and to foresee all sorts of calamitous breaches of honor.
Others, on the other hand, have said that they believed that the
men who were dismissed from the University were treated harshly
and stigmatized for the remainder of their lives. Neither of these
judgments is accurate to a great degree. The fact that these men
were able to be disciplined is a salutary one rather than a deplorable one. As regards the treatment that the, men received, the
facts peculiar to their case warrant and justify the procedure of
the Student Council. Let us hope that the Council's action will
stand as a warning to malefactors that it means business.

YES and NO
Why is there such a hub-bub about the ways and morals of
the younger generation? Is it simply the age-old tendency of
old age—always to find the kids different from those of twenty
years ago? Of course, we are different; our ways and our morals
—if we have such things—are not like those of our fathers, and
should not be judged by the same standards. Our elders unreasonably apply the inquisitory methods of their own days to our shocking behavior; naturally the result horrifies them. If some energetic
and didactic young journalist could compose a set of rules based on
the few dogmas, commandments, and rules of society which this
younger degeneration still respects, our manners might not seem
so completely immoral.
Is it youth that sins? Few of us know just exactly what sin
is; that, thank God, is one of our prize deficiencies; but is it youth
that gets its lecherous and debauched countenance smeared all over
the tabloids? Think a moment, proud parents. Which generation
can claim the Reverend Dr. Hall and his murdered play-mate?
With which group do "Flaming Ruth," as Mr. Hearst jokingly
calls her, and her aristocratic corset-vendor fall? The Snyder
murderers sinned no sin of which even the wickedest of us youngsters would boast; their, greatest offense was stupidity, which
is rather a vice of middle-age.
Some broad-minded Bishop—I insist on the veracity of such
seeming
a
paradox—recently denied that to-day's youth differed
greatly from that of his seminary years;—a statement as offensive
as that which accuses us of having no morals at all. Even here,
where education is of tantamount importance, there are those—I
blush to say it—who have admitted sipping a little too much potent
liquid. Yea; even at Hopkins where we have an Honor System
and a Student Council, there is vice; there are those who indulge
in "promiscuous petting"—who coined that lovely phrase, anyhow? The old man tells me—as everyone else's old man tells
everyone else—that in his day a girl who danced with a man
who smelled even faintly alcoholic was not long on the better invitation lists. He tells me that he was never profane before
ladies; who is not, nowadays? And there are other strange things
he tells me. . .
Hopkins does its best to be modern, and almost succeeds. Almost all of the sins in the revised list have been committed here--almost. We are strikingly deficient in one respect: we have never
had a suicide. Being ignorant of the proper persons to whom to
refer this oversight, I timidly suggest that the faculty award a
silver cup to the student dying the most artistic death; that some
potential Ph. D. write a thesis, in imitation of De Quincey, "On
Suicide as a Fine Art", and that all R. 0. T. C. officers hang
themselves on the Gilman Hall porticoes.
But let us consider the matter logically, as we should have
done to begin with, journalists, psychologists and ministers of
the Gospel view the so-called suicide epidemic with something
suspiciously akin to indignation. Why? It is most natural that
with the increasing leisure granted to young men by the comfortable financial states of their fathers, there should ensue an increasing unhappiness. Your contented cow of a man is not he
who has ample opportunity to ponder on the uselessness of life;
the George Babbitt of society has no use for suicide, because continuous hard work has not allowed him time for dissatisfaction.
Happiness and stupidity are equally the effects of hard work and
consequent unthinkingness. Melancholy, temperament, artistry,
and above all, romantic outlook, result from idleness. Then who
has more right to such qualities than the student? Further, it is
accepted fact that youth has a greater emotional range, a finer
capacity for heights of joy and depths of despondency, than. any
other age. Obviously suicide is a romantic pastime; something
your busy and contented man does not indulge in.
If suicide, then, is natural to any class, or if it is even the
right of any class, it is not at all remarkable that American universities should feel the effects of the vaunted American prosperity. Most of our sins, or whatever you wish to call them, are
petty and ignoble; our greatest virtue is a lack of ideals. If some
of the weaker members see life too clearly, and do not care to
continue in it, it is their right to leave when they please, and
no one need wonder nor object.

CONGRATULATIONS
It is with considerable pleasure that we note the promotion
in the faculty of three men who have endeared themselves to the
undergraduate body in recent years. Dr. Broadus Mitchell is
at present honorary president of the junior class; Dr. Carol Wight
is honorary president of the senior class. Dr. George Boas ha.,;
evinced an interest in undergraduate affairs by his contributions
in the past to the Black and Blue Jay, and has been mentioned
on lists of the most popular professors.

MARYLAND TRACKMEN
DEFEAT BLUE JAYS
Three

Records Fall in Hard
Fought Dual Meet

GWYNN HOPKINS STAR
• Only Black and Blue Man to
Score Two Victories
Maryland defeated Hopkins, 75
2-3 to 50 1-3, in the annual dual
meet held at College Park last Saturday.
The Old Liners evinced such a
superiority in the track event that
the outcome of the contest was never
in doubt. The Black and Blue were
able to collect only 23 points in these
races while Maryland more than
doubled this number with a total of
49.

MILITARY CIRCLE
INITIATES SIX
One army officer and five
undergraduates were initiated
by Company I, Second Regiment, of Scabbard and Blade
into membership in that organization, Saturday. The ununit
initiates
dergraduate
were Thomas N. Biddison,
Charles Harris, Henry Piet,
Charles Waters, and H. Ridgely Warfield. The initiation of
these men was held at the
Hopkins Club Saturday after
the Navy lacrosse game. Major Hamilton, of William and
Mary College, was also taken
into the organization at that
time.

Records Broken

Neuman of Maryland was the first
record breaker of the day, when he
lowered the 880 yard record, a full
second, setting a new mark of 2
minutes 2 2-5 seconds.
In the next race, the two-mile
grind, Captain Gwinn ran easily to
set a new mark of 10 min. 3-5 sec.
This race was "all Hopkins" from
the gun. For the first mile Schiebel
remained out in front. In the final
half of the race these two Jays alternated in the van and came down
the stretch, striding side by side.
With the Maryland runners far in
the rear.
The last record to fall was that in
the broad jump. Viviell of Hopkins
/

set up a new mark of 22 ft. 21
exceeding by 4 inches the old record
of Aaronson of Hopkins. The 120
Yd. high hurdle record of 16 2-5 sec.

who was pressed by Vivell throughout the race.

Sterling Work of Goal-keepers
Features Fast Game
With their coveted crown hanging in the balance, the Johns Hopkins stickmen fought and won the
greatest battle of their career, while
7,000 lacrosse fans nervously followed every play which made lacrosse history last Saturday at
Homewood.
Under the blazing afternoon sun,
the triumphant Black and Blue team
that has emerged victorious from so
many gruelling tests, put every
ounce of skill and energy forward
to come through once more the victors, this time humbling the undefeated Navy twelve by the close
margin of 6-5.
Goalkeepers Are Stone Walls

For a full five minutes while
both Middy and Jay twelves poured
a relentless fire of shots upon each
others' goal tenders, it seemed that
neither side would score with such
impregnable bulwarks to watch the
nets as Gazze and Finn. The small
Hopkins goalie seemed to cover
the whole mouth of the net, as well
aimed shots rolled off his arfns, his
legs, his chest, and even his head,
while the husky Middy net guardian's swift moving stick seemed to
have stretched until it formed a net
in front of Navy's goal.
The whole outcome of the great
struggle hinged on which of the
two hard-hitting offense machines
could first break the opposing defense. Finally, the smooth running
Hopkins machine broke through
when Biddison "goosed" the ball
from the bottom of the piled up
Navy defense past the falling Middy goal keeper after ten minutes of
hard maneuvers.

A COMPLAINT
Though the Maryland Free State is recognized as the center
of lacrosse interest in the United States, it is unfortunate indeed
that the good old game is not accorded more recognition in other
states than we think it deserves. For example, the eminent New
York Times, a paper which advertises that it covers completely
all important events in the sport world, not only failed to report'
the Hopkins-Navy game, but did not contain one lacrosse writeup in its Sunday edition.
Perhaps the sports editor of the Times might not consider
college
game attended by seven thousand spectators an impora
tant sporting event, but we doubt even that. We can only wonder
why the news of the game was omitted.

NOTE ON LAST WEEK'S TRIAL
It is almost inevitable that the honor system should break
down on occasion. Until Hopkins becomes transformed into
Utopia, we can do nothing more than hope for a close approach
to perfection. And as we have said in these columns before, we.
believe that the system at this University works as well as human
beings will let it.
Therefore, when such an unfortunate occurrence as was experienced last week is brought to light, some of the chronic worriers on the campus begin to fear for the souls of their comrades and to foresee all sorts of calamitous breaches of honor.
Others, on the other hand, have said that they believed that the
men who were dismissed from the University were treated harshly
and stigmatized for the remainder of their lives. Neither of these
judgments is accurate to a great degree. The fact that these men
were able to be disciplined is a salutary one rather than a deplorable one. As regards the treatment that the, men received, the
facts peculiar to their case warrant and justify the procedure of
the Student Council. Let us hope that the Council's action will
stand as a warning to malefactors that it means business.

YES and NO
Why is there such a hub-bub about the ways and morals of
the younger generation? Is it simply the age-old tendency of
old age—always to find the kids different from those of twenty
years ago? Of course, we are different; our ways and our morals
—if we have such things—are not like those of our fathers, and
should not be judged by the same standards. Our elders unreasonably apply the inquisitory methods of their own days to our shocking behavior; naturally the result horrifies them. If some energetic
and didactic young journalist could compose a set of rules based on
the few dogmas, commandments, and rules of society which this
younger degeneration still respects, our manners might not seem
so completely immoral.
Is it youth that sins? Few of us know just exactly what sin
is; that, thank God, is one of our prize deficiencies; but is it youth
that gets its lecherous and debauched countenance smeared all over
the tabloids? Think a moment, proud parents. Which generation
can claim the Reverend Dr. Hall and his murdered play-mate?
With which group do "Flaming Ruth," as Mr. Hearst jokingly
calls her, and her aristocratic corset-vendor fall? The Snyder
murderers sinned no sin of which even the wickedest of us youngsters would boast; their, greatest offense was stupidity, which
is rather a vice of middle-age.
Some broad-minded Bishop—I insist on the veracity of such
seeming
a
paradox—recently denied that to-day's youth differed
greatly from that of his seminary years;—a statement as offensive
as that which accuses us of having no morals at all. Even here,
where education is of tantamount importance, there are those—I
blush to say it—who have admitted sipping a little too much potent
liquid. Yea; even at Hopkins where we have an Honor System
and a Student Council, there is vice; there are those who indulge
in "promiscuous petting"—who coined that lovely phrase, anyhow? The old man tells me—as everyone else's old man tells
everyone else—that in his day a girl who danced with a man
who smelled even faintly alcoholic was not long on the better invitation lists. He tells me that he was never profane before
ladies; who is not, nowadays? And there are other strange things
he tells me. . .
Hopkins does its best to be modern, and almost succeeds. Almost all of the sins in the revised list have been committed here--almost. We are strikingly deficient in one respect: we have never
had a suicide. Being ignorant of the proper persons to whom to
refer this oversight, I timidly suggest that the faculty award a
silver cup to the student dying the most artistic death; that some
potential Ph. D. write a thesis, in imitation of De Quincey, "On
Suicide as a Fine Art", and that all R. 0. T. C. officers hang
themselves on the Gilman Hall porticoes.
But let us consider the matter logically, as we should have
done to begin with, journalists, psychologists and ministers of
the Gospel view the so-called suicide epidemic with something
suspiciously akin to indignation. Why? It is most natural that
with the increasing leisure granted to young men by the comfortable financial states of their fathers, there should ensue an increasing unhappiness. Your contented cow of a man is not he
who has ample opportunity to ponder on the uselessness of life;
the George Babbitt of society has no use for suicide, because continuous hard work has not allowed him time for dissatisfaction.
Happiness and stupidity are equally the effects of hard work and
consequent unthinkingness. Melancholy, temperament, artistry,
and above all, romantic outlook, result from idleness. Then who
has more right to such qualities than the student? Further, it is
accepted fact that youth has a greater emotional range, a finer
capacity for heights of joy and depths of despondency, than. any
other age. Obviously suicide is a romantic pastime; something
your busy and contented man does not indulge in.
If suicide, then, is natural to any class, or if it is even the
right of any class, it is not at all remarkable that American universities should feel the effects of the vaunted American prosperity. Most of our sins, or whatever you wish to call them, are
petty and ignoble; our greatest virtue is a lack of ideals. If some
of the weaker members see life too clearly, and do not care to
continue in it, it is their right to leave when they please, and
no one need wonder nor object.
